title: Nature's fortress: How cacti keep water in and predators out - Lucas C. Majure

multiple-choice.question: What is one key adaptation that allows cacti to survive in the desert?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to photosynthesize during the day

options.label: B
options.text: Their spines, which reduce water loss and provide shade

options.label: C
options.text: Their deep roots, which allow them to access water deep in the soil

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to produce flowers and seeds

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the spines on a cactus?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow the exchange of gases for photosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: To defend against predators, but also to limit water loss and provide shade

options.label: C
options.text: To store water for times of need

multiple-choice.question: How do cacti store water for times of need?

options.label: A
options.text: By limiting water loss through their spines and cuticle, and storing it in cells that contain mucilage

options.label: C
options.text: By developing deep roots to access water deep in the soil

options.label: D
options.text: By rapidly growing and spreading their lateral roots to take up available water

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the taproot in a cactus?

options.label: A
options.text: To store water for times of need

options.label: B
options.text: To anchor the cactus in place

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb water and nutrients from the soil, but not to access water deep in the soil

multiple-choice.question: How do cacti respond to a rain event in the desert?

options.label: B
options.text: By limiting water loss through their spines and cuticle

options.label: C
options.text: By rapidly growing and spreading their lateral roots to take up available water

options.label: D
options.text: By developing deep roots to access water deep in the soil

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the cuticle on a cactus?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow the exchange of gases for photosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: To limit water loss and prevent the cactus from cooling down

multiple-choice.question: How do cacti survive in a tropical rainforest?

options.label: A
options.text: By developing deep roots to access water deep in the soil

options.label: C
options.text: By using adaptations that helped their ancestors survive the desert

options.label: D
options.text: By limiting water loss through their spines and cuticle

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the cactus's spines and its ability to survive in the desert?

options.label: A
options.text: The spines are a defense mechanism against predators

options.label: B
options.text: The spines are a way for the cactus to absorb water and nutrients from the soil

options.label: C
options.text: The spines limit water loss and shade the cactus, helping it to survive in the desert

options.label: D
options.text: The spines are not related to the cactus's ability to survive in the desert

multiple-choice.question: How do cacti prepare to take full advantage of rare situations where water is readily available?

options.label: A
options.text: By limiting water loss through their spines and cuticle

options.label: C
options.text: By rapidly growing and spreading their lateral roots to take up available water

options.label: D
options.text: By developing deep roots to access water deep in the soil

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the cactus's ability to store water for times of need?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the cactus to survive in a variety of environments

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the cactus to produce flowers and seeds

options.label: C
options.text: It allows the cactus to limit water loss through its spines and cuticle

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the cactus to develop deep roots to access water deep in the soil

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the stomata on a cactus?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow the exchange of gases for photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: To limit water loss and prevent the cactus from cooling down

multiple-choice.question: How do cacti regulate their water loss in the desert?

options.label: B
options.text: By limiting water loss through their spines and cuticle

options.label: C
options.text: By rapidly growing and spreading their lateral roots to take up available water

options.label: D
options.text: By developing deep roots to access water deep in the soil

title: The surprisingly long history of electric cars - Daniel Sperling and Gil Tal

multiple-choice.question: What type of fuel did early electric vehicles rely on for power?
Which of the following was a major problem for early electric vehicles?
What innovations made internal combustion engines more appealing in the early 20th century?

options.label: D
options.text: Electric starters, mufflers, and rubber engine mounts

multiple-choice.question: Which company released the Model T, a cheap and high-quality gas-powered car, in 1908?
What was the primary reason for the decline of electric cars in the early 20th century?

options.label: C
options.text: Oil discoveries and lower gasoline prices

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of oil discoveries, lower gasoline prices, and lack of advances in battery technology

options.label: B
options.text: Gas-powered cars will become more efficient

options.label: C
options.text: Hybrid cars will become more popular

options.label: D
options.text: Electric vehicles will replace gas-powered ones altogether

title: Where will you be able to live in 20 years? - Carol Farbotko and Ingrid Boas

multiple-choice.question: What type of landmass is formed when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where the river meets a larger body of water?

options.label: A

options.text: They are only found in mountainous regions

options.label: C
options.text: They are incredibly fertile ecosystems capable of supporting abundant agriculture and marine life

options.label: D
options.text: They are barren and infertile ecosystems

multiple-choice.question: What has been the result of the frequent flooding in Mohammadpur?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The village has remained the same size

options.label: D
options.text: The village has been forced to move inland or to nearby cities

What is the impact of global warming on storms, flooding, and drought?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces their frequency and intensity

options.label: B
options.text: It has no impact on their frequency and intensity

options.label: C
options.text: It increases their frequency and intensity

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases their frequency and intensity

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of global warming on polar ice caps and sea levels?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces their size and lowers sea levels

options.label: B
options.text: It has no impact on their size and sea levels

options.label: C
options.text: It increases their size and raises sea levels

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases their size and raises sea levels

multiple-choice.question: What is the challenge facing the vulnerable populations most impacted by climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: They are often those most responsible for climate change

options.label: B
options.text: They are often those least responsible for climate change

options.label: C
options.text: They are often those with the resources to take action

options.label: D
options.text: They are often those with the knowledge to take action

options.label: A
options.text: High-lying geography and sparsely populated coastal regions

options.label: D
options.text: Low-lying geography and heavily populated coastal regions

multiple-choice.question: What is the response of the government of Bangladesh to the climate mobility crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: They have implemented projects to build concrete embankments

options.label: B
options.text: They have relocated all affected communities to safer areas

options.label: C
options.text: They have not taken any action to address the crisis

options.label: D
options.text: They have repeatedly delayed projects to build concrete embankments

options.label: A
options.text: They are relocating to a different country altogether

options.label: B
options.text: They are planting coastal mangrove forests and building up low-lying areas of land with dredged sand

options.label: C
options.text: They are lobbying on the global stage for countries with the highest emissions to reduce pollution

options.label: D
options.text: They are not taking any action to address the crisis

title: 2 questions to uncover your passion — and turn it into a career - Noeline Kirabo

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's dilemma six years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: They were unhappy with their job but had no other options.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a job that paid well but didn't match their passion.

options.label: C
options.text: They were struggling to make ends meet and had no job security.

options.label: D
options.text: They had a comfortable job but felt unfulfilled.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the first reflective question used to identify passion?

options.label: A
options.text: What skills do you have, what talents do you have, what experience do you have that you can use to build a niche in the marketplace?

options.label: B
options.text: How do you position yourself? Who are you targeting? Who do you want to sell to?

options.label: C
options.text: What makes you happy or gives you the deepest sense of fulfillment?

options.label: D
options.text: If you had all the time and the money in the world, what would you spend your time doing?

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the organization the speaker started in 2014?
According to the speaker, what is the definition of passion?

options.label: A
options.text: A feeling of happiness or joy.

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of your life experiences that give you the deepest sense of fulfillment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main focus of Esther's work, which was featured as an example?
What is the name of the person who makes amazing bags and is featured as an example of someone who turned their passion into a business?
According to the speaker, what is the key to unlocking potential?

options.label: B
options.text: Tapping into the things that give us a deep sense of fulfillment and the things that give us the deepest joy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the annual event organized by Esther, which brings together over 500 teenagers?
According to the speaker, what is the result of ceasing to work and living from the inside out?

options.label: A
options.text: You become less productive and less successful.

options.label: B
options.text: You become more focused and more driven.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of having a good education.

options.label: B
options.text: The need to work hard and persevere.

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of looking inward and tapping into one's passions.

options.label: D
options.text: The need to follow one's dreams and pursue one's goals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's initial concern about looking inward to find passion?

options.label: B
options.text: It's only for the rich or retired.

options.label: C
options.text: It's not relevant to career success.

options.label: D
options.text: It's not a priority in life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the vocational institution the speaker initially considered attending?
According to the speaker, what is the purpose of the two reflective questions used to identify passion?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify one's strengths and weaknesses.

options.label: B
options.text: B: To explore one's interests and values.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine one's career goals and aspirations.

options.label: D
options.text: To identify one's life experiences that give a deep sense of fulfillment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice to young people about finding their passion?

options.label: A
options.text: They should focus on finding a job that pays well.

options.label: B
options.text: They should look outward for opportunities.

options.label: C
options.text: They should tap into their deepest desires and passions.

options.label: D
options.text: They should follow their parents' or teachers' advice.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to turning passion into a business?

options.label: B
options.text: Having a lot of money to invest.

options.label: C
options.text: Having the right skills and positioning.

title: How the COVID-19 vaccines were created so quickly - Kaitlyn Sadtler and Elizabeth Wayne

multiple-choice.question: How quickly were vaccines for COVID-19 developed compared to traditional vaccines?

options.label: B
options.text: They were developed in a matter of months, but still required significant research and testing.

options.label: C
options.text: They cleared the threshold for emergency use in less than 11 months.

options.label: D
options.text: They were developed in a matter of weeks with minimal research and testing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of mRNA in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce proteins by encoding instructions for protein synthesis.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key ingredient in mRNA vaccines that triggers an immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: A weakened version of the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: A specific viral protein that is used to train the immune system.

multiple-choice.question: How are mRNA molecules encoded with the instructions for a specific viral protein?

options.label: A
options.text: Through genetic engineering, where researchers encode trillions of mRNA molecules with the instructions for a specific viral protein.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the lipid coating on the nanoparticles in mRNA vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the mRNA from degradation and facilitate its entry into cells.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the production of antibodies.

options.label: D
options.text: To keep the nanoparticles intact until they reach their destination.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of mRNA vaccines over traditional vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more expensive to produce.

options.label: B
options.text: They require more research and testing.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be developed in weeks and are highly flexible.

options.label: D
options.text: They contain weakened versions of live viruses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary mechanism by which mRNA vaccines work?

options.label: A
options.text: By activating the immune system through the production of antibodies in response to a specific viral protein.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of adding sugars and salt to the nanoparticles in mRNA vaccines?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the production of antibodies.

options.label: C
options.text: To keep the nanoparticles intact until they reach their destination.

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the mRNA from degradation.

multiple-choice.question: At what temperature are mRNA vaccines typically stored?
What is the main advantage of mRNA vaccines in terms of flexibility?

options.label: A
options.text: They can be developed in weeks.

options.label: B
options.text: They can be adapted to treat new diseases by swapping out a single component.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be produced in large quantities.

options.label: D
options.text: They can be stored at room temperature.

title: The secret society of the Great Dismal Swamp - Dan Sayers

multiple-choice.question: What was the Great Dismal Swamp known as by 1728?
What is the significance of the Great Dismal Swamp in the context of American history?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a major site of colonial settlement

options.label: B
options.text: It was a place of refuge for enslaved people and Indigenous Americans

options.label: C
options.text: It was a major industrial center

options.label: D
options.text: It was a site of significant military battles

options.text: It was the first systematic excavation of the Great Dismal Swamp

options.label: B
options.text: It was conducted by a team of archaeologists from a specific university

options.label: C
options.text: It was a small-scale excavation that found only a few artifacts

options.label: D
options.text: It marked the beginning of a long-term research project

What is the estimated date of the dispersal of the secret communities in the Great Dismal Swamp?

options.label: D
options.text: During or soon after the American Civil War

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the ceramic and stone items found in the Great Dismal Swamp?

options.label: A
options.text: They were used for decorative purposes

options.label: B
options.text: They were used for ceremonial purposes

options.label: C
options.text: They were used for practical purposes and were likely left by ancient Indigenous people and reused and modified by others later on

options.label: D
options.text: They were not found in the Great Dismal Swamp

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of habitable islands in the Great Dismal Swamp at the time of the secret communities?

options.label: D
options.text: There is no record of a specific number

multiple-choice.question: What does the Great Dismal Swamp represent in the context of American history and culture?

options.label: A
options.text: A major site of colonial settlement

options.label: B
options.text: A place of refuge for enslaved people and Indigenous Americans and a symbol of resistance against slavery and colonization

options.label: D
options.text: A site of significant military battles

title: A woman's fury holds lifetimes of wisdom - Tracee Ellis Ross

multiple-choice.question: What was the situation that triggered a woman's strong emotional response at the post office?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone cutting in front of her in line.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone moved her out of the way without her consent.

multiple-choice.question: What was the woman's initial emotional response to the situation at the post office?
According to the speaker, what is the connection between seemingly innocuous and horrific situations involving women's bodies?

options.label: C
options.text: The innocuous makes space for the horrific.

options.label: D
options.text: The horrific makes space for the innocuous.

multiple-choice.question: Why do men often feel like they can "help themselves" to women's bodies, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are unaware of the impact of their actions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are trying to assert their dominance.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are fundamentally less moral.

options.label: D
options.text: Because this is a very big blind spot for most men.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker suggesting that women have been trained to do when they feel fury?

options.label: C
options.text: To swallow their furious feelings and try to make sense of nonsense.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the responsibility of men in changing their bad behavior towards women?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore the problem and hope it goes away.

options.label: B
options.text: To blame women for their behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: To take responsibility for changing their behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: To expect women to change their behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker encouraging women to do with their fury?

options.label: A
options.text: To suppress it and pretend it doesn't exist.

options.label: B
options.text: To express it openly and loudly.

options.label: C
options.text: To acknowledge it, give it language, and share it in safe places.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore it and focus on being pleasant.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the significance of the fury that women feel?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a sign of weakness.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a sign of strength.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a sign of emotional instability.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the current state of the movement towards women's equality?

options.label: B
options.text: It is shifting and gaining momentum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker encouraging men to be as allies in the movement towards women's equality?

options.label: B
options.text: To be accountable and self-reflective, compassionate and open.

title: How do you know what's true? - Sheila Marie Orfano

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe a situation in which individuals give significantly different but equally conceivable accounts of the same event?
Which two conditions usually occur for the Rashomon effect to happen?

options.label: A
options.text: There's no evidence to verify what really happened and there's no pressure to achieve closure.

options.label: B
options.text: There's no evidence to verify what really happened and there's pressure to achieve closure.

options.label: C
options.text: There's evidence to verify what really happened and there's no pressure to achieve closure.

options.label: D
options.text: There's evidence to verify what really happened and there's pressure to achieve closure.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can influence people to subconsciously reshape their memories in ways that cast a positive light on their actions?
What can happen when we later recall an event that we previously encoded accurately?

options.label: A
options.text: We typically remember the original experience.

options.label: B
options.text: We typically remember the embellished memory instead of the original experience.

options.label: D
options.text: We remember a mix of both the original experience and the embellished memory.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Japanese author who wrote the short story "In a Grove," which is also known as "Rashomon"?
In what year did Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa adapt two of Akutagawa's stories into one film?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to more accurate decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to more reliable decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to less accurate and less reliable decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to no impact on decisions.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can different versions of the same event tell us about the time, place, and people involved?

options.label: B
options.text: Something about the time, place, and people involved.

options.label: D
options.text: Something about the time and place.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the story "Rashomon"?

options.label: A
options.text: The story is about the complexity of truth and human memory.

options.label: B
options.text: The story is about the unreliability of eyewitnesses.

options.label: C
options.text: The story is about a samurai who is found dead in a quiet bamboo grove.

options.label: D
options.text: The story is about the impact of personal backgrounds on an expert's perception.

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of embracing the ambiguity in the story "Rashomon"?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no value in embracing the ambiguity.

options.label: B
options.text: The value is in finding a definitive answer.

options.label: C
options.text: The value is in understanding the complexity of truth and human memory.

options.label: D
options.text: The value is in making group decisions.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can influence people's perception of an event?

options.label: A
options.text: A security summit between the United States and Arab States

options.label: B
options.text: A scientific study with different results

options.label: C
options.text: A news report with different versions of the same event

title: Can you be awake and asleep at the same time? - Masako Tamaki

multiple-choice.question: What type of sleep-like state is exhibited by brainless jellyfish, where they pulse less and respond more slowly to food and movement?
Which of the following is an example of asymmetrical sleep in humans?

options.label: B
options.text: Lighter sleep in one hemisphere and deeper sleep in the other

multiple-choice.question: Why do dolphins sleep unihemispherically?

options.label: B
options.text: To stay alert to threats from the depths

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of unihemispheric sleep in fur seals?

options.label: B
options.text: To stay alert to threats from the depths

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where humans experience deeper sleep in their right hemisphere and lighter sleep in their left hemisphere

options.text: Because the data from the first night is not reliable due to the "first night effect"

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of asymmetrical sleep in humans?

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Why should you read Toni Morrison’s “Beloved”? - Yen Pham

multiple-choice.question: What is the title of Toni Morrison's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about the suffering wrought by slavery and the wounds that persist in its wake?
In "Beloved," what is the name of the main character who escaped from enslavement?
What is the nature of the spirit that haunts Sethe's house in "Beloved"?

options.label: A
options.text: A malevolent entity that seeks to harm Sethe

options.label: B
options.text: A manifestation of Sethe's guilt and trauma

options.label: C
options.text: A ghost that is the product of an unspeakable trauma

options.label: D
options.text: A supernatural being with its own motivations

multiple-choice.question: In "Beloved," what is the significance of the two tiny handprints on the cake?

options.label: A
options.text: They symbolize the love between Sethe and her daughter

options.label: B
options.text: They represent the trauma inflicted by slavery

options.label: C
options.text: They signify the presence of the ghost

options.label: D
options.text: They are a sign of hope in the novel

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of "Beloved" as it relates to love?

options.label: A
options.text: The difficulty of love in the face of social conventions

options.label: C
options.text: The redeeming power of love in the face of trauma

options.label: D
options.text: The novel explores the complexity of love in various contexts, including its destructive effects when love is taken away

multiple-choice.question: How does Morrison portray the dehumanizing effects of the slave trade in "Beloved"?

options.label: A
options.text: By depicting enslaved people as animals with monetary value

options.label: B
options.text: By showing the physical and emotional scars of enslaved people

options.label: C
options.text: By highlighting the role of love in the lives of enslaved people

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the stream-of-consciousness sequence written from Sethe's perspective in "Beloved"?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the beauty of language in the novel

options.label: B
options.text: It captures the complexity of Sethe's emotions

options.label: C
options.text: It conveys the trauma of slavery through Sethe's memories of subjugation and moments of tenderness

options.label: D
options.text: It showcases the author's writing style

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of "Beloved" as it relates to hope and freedom?

options.label: A
options.text: That hope is lost in the face of trauma

options.label: B
options.text: That freedom is not explicitly stated, but the novel urges readers to ponder the power we have over each other, and to use that power wisely

options.label: C
options.text: That hope can be found in the face of darkness

options.label: D
options.text: That freedom is only possible through the power of love

multiple-choice.question: How does Morrison blend perspectives and manipulate perspectives and timelines in "Beloved"?

options.label: B
options.text: By shifting between different time periods

options.label: C
options.text: By exploring conflicting viewpoints on reality

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the character Paul D. in "Beloved"?

options.label: A
options.text: He represents the power of love in the face of trauma

options.label: B
options.text: He symbolizes the destructive power of hate

options.label: C
options.text: He captures the complexity of human emotions

options.label: D
options.text: He represents the limitations of human perspective, and how people cope with trauma in different ways

multiple-choice.question: In "Beloved," what is the significance of the character's shifting memories and the ways in which they align perfectly to capture the collective trauma that haunts the story?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the power of love in the face of trauma

options.label: B
options.text: It showcases the author's writing style

options.label: C
options.text: It conveys the trauma of slavery through the characters' memories and experiences

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the limitations of human perspective, and how people cope with trauma in different ways

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the destructive power of hate

options.label: B
options.text: It showcases the author's writing style

options.label: C
options.text: It conveys the importance of empathy and understanding in breaking the cycle of trauma

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the limitations of human perspective, and how people cope with trauma in different ways

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the power of love in the face of trauma

options.label: C

options.label: B
